Surface chemical-functionalization of ultrathin two-dimensional nanomaterials for electrocatalysis

a b s t r a c t
In the past few decades, with the development of energy conversion and storage technology, twodimensional (2D) ultrathin nanomaterials with single or few atomic layers have been extensively studied as efficient electrocatalysts due to their unique physical, chemical, and electronic properties. The unique ultrathin structure provides an alternative way of modifying the surface phase or electronic structure for engineering the intrinsic electrocatalysts properties. Here, we focus on recent attempts to discuss the concerning surface chemical modification strategies of surface atoms incorporation, defect engineering, and surface structure modulation, which could respectively enhance the intrinsic electrical conductivity, optimizing the reaction energy barrier while maintaining the primary 2D structural stability. Following this review, we listed the surface-functional 2D materials for enhanced electrocatalytic processes involved in the water splitting, oxygen/nitrogen reduction reactions, as well as density functional theoretical (DFT) calculation to study the relationship between electronic structure, adsorption energy, and apparent activity sites. Finally, we also present some challenges and opportunities of surface chemical-functionalization of ultrathin 2D nanomaterials for electrocatalysis.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Increasingly severe environmental pollution and energy crisis urgently require the emergence of newclean and renewable system for energy conversion and storage, such as water electrolysis, fuel cells, and metal-air batteries, and so on [1e4]. The core of these advanced energy-related systems is a series of hydrogen- and oxygen-related electrocatalytic processes. The water splitting is responsible for fuel generation (H2 and O2) through hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER) at the cathode and the anode, respectively, while the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) and hydrogen/cathode oxidation reaction of fuel cell for power generation [5e7]. From the chemical perspective, chemical bond breakage and re-formation under an external electricity condition are essence of catalysis [8]. For instance, HER
shuangyinwang@hnu.edu.cn
relies on the splitting of HeO bonds in H2O molecules and their conversion into HeH bonds in H2 molecules [9]. The splitting of OeO bonds in O2 molecules under the extra electric field is the theoretical basis of fuel cells and metal-air batteries [6]. The key scientific issues of nitrogen reduction reactions (NRR) for NH3 preparation are the activation of N^N triple bond, and the coupling of NeH bonds under the external field [10]. Electrochemical reactions are an efficiency way for chemical bond through the gain and loss of electrons to achieve clean methods of converting and storing electrical energy, in which external electricity is needed to overcome the overpotential caused by the activation energy barrier [11,12]. Heterogeneous electrocatalysis is a process that can accelerate electrochemical reactions on the surface of electrode materials. However, the sluggish kinetics of the multi-electron transfer OER, ORR and NRR processes limit the performance of corresponding reaction [10,13]. Conventionally, catalysts for these reactions are based on precious-metals-based electrocatalyst such as Pt, Ir, and Ru, but the poor stability, and their cost cannot meet their large-scale application [14]. Thus, the development of highperformance and low-cost catalysts by material design or functionalization have become crucial.
According to the electrocatalytic reaction principles, the number of active sites, the electrical conductivity, and the reaction energy barrier determined the catalytic activities [15,16]. Therefore, twodimensional (2D) nanomaterials has gradually attracted much attention because of its special layer structure. Most pristine 2D nanomaterials with low activities are not suitable for electrocatalysis because of their limited active sites, low electrical conductivity, and even poor long-term stability. However, after 2D materials exfoliated into atomic-scale thickness, surface areas were not only enhanced for offering abundant electrochemical active sites, but also almost all atoms were exposed for functionalization at atomic level. The surface chemical-functionalization strategies through surface atom incorporation, defect engineering, and structure modulation can provide efficient approach to simultaneously optimize the multiple catalytic conditions mentioned above. The number of active sites is connected directly with surface defects, and coordination environment [17e20]. The electrical conductivity and the reaction energy barrier were determined by the carrier concentration, specific band structure near the Fermi level, and charge distribution [21,22]. Surface heteroatoms incorporation and defect engineering could promote the electronelectron correlation effect and trigger electron transfer for enhancing the electrical conductivity, even turning part of nonactive sites at surface into active sites [23]. Thus, regulating surface charge will be an efficient perspective for optimizing electrical conductivity and the reaction energy barrier for high activity sites at physical level. The catalytic performance often depends more on the adsorption behavior of reactive molecules on the catalyst surface during the reaction process. These chemical-functionalization strategies could regulate the electron structure (particularly the surface charge distribution), reflecting the surface adsorption behavior indirectly. In general, enriched localized electrons could enhance adsorption and activation of reaction molecules to reduce the reaction energy barrier [23]. In addition, the durability of a catalyst determines the life of the electrocatalytic systems for practical applications. The surface chemical modifications do not destroy the main ultrathin 2D structure only by molecular modification or local lattices distortion to ensure the stability of nanomaterials during the electrocatalytic process. Even sometimes, the surface molecular or new chemical bonds could retain or promote its specificity for long-term applications. In a word, surface chemical-functionalization of ultrathin 2D nanomaterials chemical modifications provide a new effective strategy to modulate the electrocatalytic activities and stability for application.
With the global boom in graphene since 2004, ultrathin twodimensional (2D) nanomaterials are currently receiving a great deal of attention for both fundamental studies and practical applications owing to their unique properties such as large surface-tovolume ratio, mechanical flexibility, fast interfacial charge transfer, and facile electrochemical reactions [23e27]. However, for electrocatalytic applications, most pristine 2D nanomaterials have very low catalytic performance [28]. For example, graphene presents low intrinsic activity because the delocalized p bonding network of graphene makes the adsorption of reaction intermediates very endothermic. Since the nitrogen-doped carbon nanotubes (N-CNT) were discovered to have promising alternatives ORR performance to Pt, tremendous progress has been made in development of modified graphene [29,30]. Other than graphene, many new types of 2D nanomaterials and their derivatives have been explored and applied in electrocatalysis, including: graphene-based materials, black phosphorus (BP), 2D transition metals, layered transitionmetal hydroxides, MXenes, 2D Metal Organic Framework (MOFs), and so on. Another classic example is 2D molybdenum disulfide (MoS2), which has a promising active for HER as its hydrogen adsorption Gibbs free energy (DGH*) is only 0.08 eV,
lower than that of Pt [31,32]. Nørskov, Chorkendorff, and coworkers found in 2005 that the edge sites of MoS2 have a good HER activity. Mo-edge sites were identified as active sites for HER and the theoretical free energy of adsorption of hydrogen on this metallic edge is similar to Pt active sites [32]. Layer Transitionmetal oxides (TMOs) and hydroxides (TMHs) is also a kind of electric catalysts widely studied by researchers, especially layered double hydroxides (LDHs) [26]. Most 2D TMOs or TMHs can be used as electrocatalysts directlywithout furthermodification, their weak electron transfer abilities usually hinder their electrochemical properties [33]. MXene is a new 2D nanomaterials discovered in 2011, which possess the advantage of metallic conductivity and hydrophily suitable for electrocatalysis [34,35]. However, many highly active metal nitrides (such as cobalt, nickel, and iron) were not easy to introduced into MXene. Recently, with the attention of Metal Organic Frameworks (MOFs) applied in electrocatalysis due to their tailorable structures, and large surface area [36,37]. 2D MOFs highly accessible active sites were gradually developed. Those 2D nanomaterials provide an ideal platform for regulating intrinsic physical and properties surface chemical-functionalization strategies [38]. To overcome the shortcomings of those classic 2D nanomaterials, including surface heteroatom doping, defect engineering, heterostructure construction, and surface molecule functionalization. More importantly, those methods with surface electron transfer or local lattices distortion does not destroy the main 2D structure that is vital for practical applications. In addition to non-precious metal catalysts, the application of surface modification technology also provides a new opportunity for the efficient utilization of 2D precious metal catalyst.
In this review, we firstly describe the surface chemicalfunctionalization principles, including surface heteroatom doping, defect engineering, and surface molecule functionalization for ultrathin two-dimensional nanomaterials. The “d-band center theory” describes the relationship between the catalyst's band structure and its chemical surface adsorption behavior, guiding us for the catalyst design [43]. Then, we provide a summary of surface modified 2D nan catalysts for the major electrocatalytic reactions (ORR, OER, HER, and NRR), analyze the catalysis origins through combination of DFT calculations, which are widely adopted to offer a precise description of the electronic structure of catalysts and the relationship between catalytic activity and catalysts. Finally, we present some challenges and opportunities of surface chemicalfunctionalization of ultrathin 2D nanomaterials for electrocatalysis.

sections.heading: 2. Engineering protocols by surface chemical functionalization
sections.text: As mentioned above, the number of active sites, the electrical conductivity, and especially the adsorption energy determines the catalytic activities of 2D nanomaterials. In this section, from the perspective of regulating electron structure, we briefly summarize three surface chemical-functionalized strategies for improving the catalysis performance of 2D catalysts, including heteroatom doping (non-metal-atom doping or metal-atom doping), defect engineering, and surface molecule functionalization (non-covalent interactions and covalent interactions).

sections.heading: 2.1. Heteroatom doping
sections.text:
Heteroatoms doping is an effective method for 2D nanomaterials to tailor elemental composition and electronic properties, which would reduce the adsorption barrier in electrocatalytic process. Surface heteroatoms doping could promote the electronelectron correlation effect and trigger electron transfer for enhancing the electrical conductivity, even turning part of non-
active sites at surface into active sites. In addition, because of the different radius of heteroatom, doping defects are introduced into the lattice of the catalyst to further effect the catalytic performance. To date, both the experiment and theoretical calculations have demonstrated that heteroatom doping can impart catalytic activity effectively for various 2D nanomaterials such as graphene, MoS2, etc. It is generally divided into two categories: non-metal-atom doping and metal-atom doping. Non-metal-atom doping normally includes single element doping (Ne, Be, Oe, Se, Pe), the dual-doping (BeN, NS etc.) and triple-doping (NePeS, BeNeP) into the 2D material framework, such as graphene. Metal-atom doping is mainly used for synthesizing single-atom catalysts on 2D material surface, such as Pt single atom on graphene. Heteroatom doping is an efficient and controllable method to enhance the catalytic performance of 2D nanocatalysts for electrocatalytic processes such as the ORR, OER, HER, and NRR.
Non-Metal-Atom Doping. Since Dai and co-worker's success developed vertically aligned nitrogen doped carbon nanotube (CNT) as highly efficient electrocatalyst for ORR in 2009, carbonbased materials doped with non-metal-atom as efficient and lowcost electrocatalysts have been widely investigated [29]. Doping nitrogen into graphene (N-graphene) could be considered as the pioneer of 2D electrocatalysts for effectively tailoring the electrochemical properties of graphene. Compare with carbon, nitrogen with greater electronegativity could facilitate the conjugation between the nitrogen lone pair electrons and the graphene p-system [44,45].
The nitrogen doping could induce charge transfer in the doping sites of the carbon materials, which could cause the charge redistribution in the p-conjugated system around the heteroatom dopants and tune the chemical activities of the electrocatalyst. Inspired by this discovery, graphene doped with other heteroatoms such as O, B, S, and P have been developed for electrocatalysis. These heteroatoms usually exist similar but different atomic radius, so defect regions could be formed at the edge or basal plane as active sites for electrocatalysis [46,47].
In addition to graphene, non-metal-atom doping has been extended to other 2D materials, such as oxygen doped MoS2 [47]. Oxygen incorporation can effectively regulate the electronic structure of MoS2 and further improve its HER performance. Beyond single element doping, double- or triple-doped 2D nanomaterials have been prepared and showed significantly greater electrocatalytic activity than single-doped materials. We have successfully prepared BeN co-doped vertically-aligned carbon nanotube and graphene, which indicated comparable ORR performance to the commercial Pt/C electrode and much better methanol and CO tolerance and excellent durability [48]. Followed by the BeN co-doped nanotube, numerously multiple-atom-doped graphene nanosheets (N/S, N/P, NePeS, BeNeP dopants) exhibited superior performance compared to their single doped counterparts.
Metal-Atom Doping. According to the small size effect of materials, when the size of metal nanocrystalline drops to cluster or single atom, its energy level structure and electron structure will change fundamentally, which makes the sub-nanometer-sized metal clusters or single-atom metal with better catalytic activity or selectivity [49e51]. However, owing to the high surface energy of isolated atom, most available single-atom catalysts (SACs) keep a low loading (usually near 0.1 wt%-7.5%) to avoid aggregation. Doping 2D nanomaterials with metal atoms are usually developed to prepare singe-atom catalysts for various efficient catalytic processes [52], which attribute to the large specific surface area and coordination ability of 2D materials for effective anchoring single metal atom [53e55]. For example, N-graphene has been regarded as an excellent substrate for SACs, due to the abundant N species as anchoring sites and the higher surface energy around N atoms.
Dispersed single-atom Pt, Cu(I), Co with high density and low valent metal centers were successfully anchored on nitrogen-doped graphene lattice [56e59]. In addition, nitrogen or sulfur dopants or group as coordination sites were introduced into the substrates for capturing and anchoring isolated metal [60].
Other than graphene, single metal-atom doping can tune the electronic structure and improve the electrocatalytic activity of 2D transition-metal dichalcogenides (TMDs). It has been proven that the S edge site is catalytically active of 2D TMDs for HER [61e63]. In MoS2 matrix, there are six S atoms aroundMo to form SeMo.When (Pt, Ag, Pd, Co, Ni) metal atoms substitute the Mo atoms, their position shift toward one side and bondwith only four S atoms. The other two unsaturated S-atoms can act as active site like the S edge, increasing the total number of active sites [64]. In addition, single metal atom doping can reduce energy barrier to improve the HER performance of LDH as well as OER activity. For example, NiFelayered double hydroxide (NiFe-LDH) has emerged as a promising electrocatalyst for OER but with poor HER performance, in alkaline solutions. The as-synthesized Ru-doped NiFe-LDH nanosheets exhibit excellent HER performance, even higher than those of noble metal Pt/C and reported electrocatalysts. Both experimental and theoretical results reveal that the introduction of Ru atoms can reduce energy barrier of the Volmer step for accelerating its HER kinetics [65].
These findings demonstrate the potential of non-metal-atom and metal-atom doping for enhanced catalytic ability of 2D nanomaterials, provides a promising alternative to the precious metal catalysts for exploring low cost and highly active electrocatalysts.

sections.heading: 2.2. Defect engineering
sections.text:
Defects are commonly recognized as the active sites of 2D nanomaterials for electrocatalytic processes [66]. The Defect/vacancy can elicit the charge-transfer phenomenon and effectively adjust the charge distribution without destroying pristine lattices. It also naturally adjust the local charge distribution around the heteroatom for enhance electrical conductivity to optimize the reaction energy barrier present in Coulomb force.[24] Defects sites normally includes the edge sites and the plane topological defect sites. Edge is the natural defect, and the plane topological defects like point defects (vacancies, voids, StoneeWales defects, etc.) and line defects (dislocation, grain boundaries, etc.) are unavoidable in the process of synthesis or reprocessing. For example, the DFT calculations were performed to confirm that the edge carbon atoms and the plane topological defects in graphene had higher charge density contributed to chemically active for the ORR [67e70]. They can locally altered bond lengths, long-term deformations, and rehybridized electron orbitals, which will lead to a considerable modification of electron trajectories. At the same times, compared to pristine graphene, oxygen adsorption on defective graphene strengthened, resulting in trapping of the oxygen onto defects [71].
The edge defects and the doped defects in basal plan ofMoS2 has been proven as the catalytically active for HER. As a result, defect engineering has been widely used for 2D nanomaterial to increase their electrocatalytic activities [72]. Defects like point defects and line defects are unavoidable in crystalline materials following the second law of thermodynamics. However, controllable introduction of defects in 2D materials are essential. For example, Jia et al. developed a defect-rich graphene by the removal of nitrogen dopants in N-graphene, showing higher ORR activity [70]. We etched graphene with Ar plasma to increase the edge sites on the graphene plan for excellent ORR performance [69]. For example, Liu et al. reported that vacancies formed in ultrathin CoSe2 nanosheets through ultrasonic treatment can serve as the active sites for the OER [73]. We etched Co3O4 nanosheets with Ar plasma to introduce
abundant oxygen vacancy for enhanced OER performance. These controllable defects introduction provides the potential for the precise study of defects and their effect on reaction mechanisms [74].

sections.heading: 2.3. Surface molecule functionalization
sections.text:
Surface molecule functionalization is another important method for designing high-performance electrocatalysts. Compared to the harsh condition for heteroatom doping and defects engineering, the molecule functionalization process is milder [75,76]. The molecules can act as electron-donors or-acceptors modify the electronic structure of 2D materials, giving rise to significant changes in the electronic to regulate the electrical properties [77,78]. According to the type of the molecule and 2D materials, there are two kinds surface molecule functionalization pattern: non-covalent interactions and covalent interactions.
Non-covalent interactions. This typical interaction between the molecule and the 2D materials are Vander Waals force, electrostatic interaction, hydrogen bonding, coordination bonds or pep stacking interactions. The molecule on the surface of 2D materials can change the local charge state of the materials and affect the electrocatalytic activity. Such as the melamine interacted graphene [79], poly (diallyl dimethylammonium chloride) (PDDA) adsorbed carbon nanotubes (CNTs) [80], composites of poly (3,4- ethylenedioxythiophene): poly (styrenesulfonate) (PEDOT: PSS) functionalized reduced graphene oxide (rGO) [81], graphene nanoribbon adsorbed with TCNE [82], and so on.
Covalent interactions. This typical interaction between the molecule and the 2D materials are along with covalent bond form. Take nitrobenzene functionalized graphene for example, the strong electron-accepting ability of nitrobenzene could dope at graphene edge via covalent CeC bonding which would draw an electron from carbon atoms from the graphene sheet and change the natural electronic structure of graphene [83e85]. Besides, pyridine moieties covalent modified carbon nanotube with electronic properties of N-containing also show the improvement of ORR [86].

sections.heading: 3. Surface-functional 2D nanomaterials for oxygen reduction reaction
sections.text: Oxygen electrocatalysis is one of the most studied topics in the fields of electrochemistry and catalysis for energy conversion applications. The activity of the ORR is sluggish kinetics and recognized as kinetically, limiting corresponding device performance. An effective and efficient ORR electrocatalyst is one of the key targets for fuel cell development. Fundamentally, the ORR process in aqueous solutions is consists of multiple reaction steps involving oxygen-containing species such as O*, OH*, and OOH* [92,93]. The ORR performance is related to the thermodynamic adsorption energetics of these intermediates and the kinetic energy barriers [94]. The most well studied ORR electrocatalysts are precious Pt and its alloys. To date, a wide range of 2D nanomaterials have shown promising ORR activity. Here we mainly focus on the surface chemical-functional ORR electrocatalysts, including defective graphene, molecular modified graphene, ultrathin MOFs and so on.

sections.heading: 3.1. Doped graphene
sections.text:
For ORR, doping graphene with other non-metallic heteroatoms is the most widely applied and most effective approaches for inducing intramolecular charge transfer in graphene frameworks and for enhancing electrocatalytic activity. Generally, the origin of this activity may be the unique electronic structure for reactant/ intermediate adsorption and variable nanostructure which
increases the number of exposed active sites. Doping graphene includes: nitrogen-doped graphene, Other heteroatom-doped graphene, multiple-atom (dual- or triple-) doped graphene.
N-graphene is the most studied graphene-based electrocatalyst. The similar atomic size between Nitrogen and carbon minimized the lattice mismatch in the doping process. At the same time, the lower electronegative of N change the electron configuration nearby carbon atoms and by creating defect structures to enable stronger oxygen adsorption. N-graphene is the earliest studied and the most important metal-free electrocatalyst for the ORR. Compared to metal-based electrocatalysts (Pt), N-graphene shows excellent 4e pathway ORR activity and has even superior to Pt/C (Fig. 2) [96]. The most important features of N-graphene are its tolerance to the fuel (e.g., methanol and CO) present in the anode chamber of fuel cells, which largely prevents the crossover effect (Fig. 2j, l). Due to its stable chemical structure, N-graphene also exhibits good stability in alkaline conditions. Both lots of experimental and theoretical showed that the ORR activity of N-graphene is strongly dependent on the nitrogen doping sites and types. In Ngraphene, Nitrogen can exist in three different forms, including pyridine-like, pyrrole-like, and graphitic nitrogen (Fig. 1). Several research groups have reported that the pyridinic N was the active site to enhance the ORR activity of the N-doped carbon nanomaterial [97e103]. Besides nitrogen, other non-metal elements (e.g., B, S, P) with different atom size and electronegativity have been doped into the graphene by physical or chemical approaches. Similar to nitrogen, those elements can also change the electronic properties of pristine graphene. But the doping level of these materials is normally lower than that of N-graphene [104e107]. The Pdoped graphite layers were found to have more defects in the graphitic structure than the non-phosphorus graphite layers, exhibiting a high electrocatalytic activity, long-term stability, and excellent tolerance to cross-over effects of methanol for the ORR in an alkaline medium.110.
Multiple-atom doped graphene. As early as 2011, Wang et al. used a CVD method to synthesize graphene with tunable Be and Ne atoms simply by thermal annealing graphene oxide in the presence of boric acid under ammonia for excellent ORR performance (even better than the commercial Pt/C), as shown in Fig. 2. Using DFT, they then investigated the band gap energy dependency on the doping level, spin density, and charge density in BCNgraphene systems with different B/N concentrations and moiety type. B12C77N11H26 should have the highest chemical reactivity or the best catalytic performance [79]. Then double- or triple-doped graphene (e.g., B/N, S/N, P/N or N/B/P, N/S/P) have also been studied and show significantly enhanced ORR activity compared to their single-doped counterparts [48,109e118]. DFT calculations reveal that the origin of this enhancement is the synergistic effect between the two or more different dopant elements. Theoretical analysis indicates that dual dopants can tailor the electron-donor properties of nearby carbon atoms to enhance intermediate adsorption (see Fig. 3).

sections.heading: 3.2. Defective graphene
sections.text:
Defects are also recognized as the active sites of graphene for ORR processes. A theoretical study by Tang et al. also showed that the pristine graphene with specific defects has a higher ORR activity than N-graphene [119]. As shown in Fig. 4B(a), topological defects at the edge have a greater effect on overpotential than doping and edge effects. However, it is still a big challenge to introduce, characterize and distinguish defects. Jia et al. introduced different types of topological defects into the graphene lattice via the removal of intentionally doped heteroatoms, and directly observed various defects on the edge of graphene at atomic level
[68]. Tao et al. developed edge-rich and dopant-free graphene, CNTs and graphite as efficient metal-free electrocatalysts by the Arplasma etching. The plasma etching increased the active edge sites on the carbon surface plane to facilitate the ORR catalytic activity. The edge-rich graphene maintains an integrity structure without causing serious damage on themacroscopic structure caused by the plasma treatment. Notably, the edge-rich graphene electrode shows remarkable ORR electrocatalytic activities with better fuel selectivity and higher long-term stability than that of the commercially available Pt/C electrode. This work confirms the important role of edge carbon in efficient ORR electrocatalysis without interruption by any other dopants [120].
3.3. Molecule modified graphene
The molecule on the graphene can change the local charge state to affect the electrocatalytic activity. Chiu et al. developed disordered graphene to absorb melamine to research the electronic state, the charge concentrations reflected in the shift of the Raman G-band can be changed by varying the coverage of the adsorbates, and the density functional theory (DFT) also indicate a larger charge transfer in the grapheneemelamine complex occurs. After that, Wang et al. first developed poly diallyl dimethylammonium chloride) (PDDA) functionalized/adsorbed carbon nanotubes (CNTs) as efficient ORR electrocatalyst beyond heteroatomic doping by simply through physical adsorption [81]. As it shown in Fig. 5a, simply through physical adsorption, with polyelectrolyte chains containing positively charged nitrogen moieties could also create net positive charge on carbon atoms of nitrogen-free CNTs via intermolecular charge-transfer. By XPS measurement, the charged nitrogen, Nþ of pure PDDA compared to the PDDA functionalized CNTs confirms the charge transfer between PDDA and CNTs. Afterwards, composites of poly (3,4-ethylenedioxythiophene): poly (styrenesulfonate) (PEDOT: PSS) and reduced graphene oxide (rGO) have been prepared and used as electrocatalysts for ORR [80]. Hybridization of PEDOT: PSS with rGO and the subsequent treatment with H2SO4 can significantly increase the electrical conductivity of PEDOT because of alternation of the PEDOT resonating ground states through strong pep interaction and segregation and partial removal of PSS chains from PEDOT: PSS [82]. On the other hand, the positively charged PEDOT backbones have electron-withdrawing ability to create net positive charges on rGO sheets via intermolecular charge transfer. Accordingly, the resultant PEDOT: PSS/rGO composite films are expected to exhibit synergistically enhanced electrocatalytic activity for ORR. Besides, the DFT calculations were performed to predict the structures and catalytic activities of graphene nanoribbon adsorbed with TCNE. The adsorption of TCNE results in electron transfer from graphene to TCNE and redistribution of charge on the graphene nanoribbons [83]. The existence of
defect enhances the adsorption of TCNE and the active sites are mostly located near the edges. These predictions show that of TCNE-adsorbed graphene could be a good metal-free catalyst to replace Pt-based catalysts for ORR.
Recently, Wang et al. developed nitrobenzene functionalized graphene as efficient electrocatalyst for ORR (Fig. 5b) [76]. The strong electron-accepting ability of nitrobenzene could dope at graphene edge via covalent CeC bonding which would draw an electron from carbon atoms from the graphene sheet and change the natural electronic structure of graphene. The ORR catalytic activity of the molecule-doped graphene was enhanced through the charge transfer process between the linked molecule, nitrobenzene, and graphene. Raman characterizations confirmed the charge transfer process. The electrochemical characterizations proved that the molecular-doping- induced charge transfer strategy could enhance the catalytic activity for ORR like N-doped graphene.

sections.heading: 3.4. Mxenes
sections.text: In 2011, a new category of 2D nanomaterials named MXene was discovered [139,140]. MXene-type materials are very suitable for electrocatalysis because they possess metallic conductivity and are hydrophilic. For ORR, mxene is more suitable as a carrier or support. Using Ti3C2Tx MXene as a support, a twofold activity improvement of pristine FeeNeC is realized. The marriage of FeN4 moiety and MXene can induce remarkable Fe3d electron delocalization and spin-state transition of Fe(II) ions. The lower local electron density and higher spin state of the Fe(II) centers greatly favor the Fe dz2 electron transfer, and lead to an easier oxygen adsorption and reduction on active FeN4 sites, and thus an enhanced ORR activity. The optimized catalyst shows a two- and fivefold higher specific ORR activity than those of pristine catalyst and Pt/C, respectively, even exceeding most FeeNeC catalysts ever reported [35].

sections.heading: 4. Surface-functional 2D nanomaterials for oxygen evolution reaction
sections.text: The OER is a 4e transfer process and is the reverse reaction of the ORR. Many studies have demonstrated that various 2D nanostructured electrocatalysts can efficiently catalyze the OER and significant development has been achieved in recent years. In this section, we first discuss the fundamental principles of the OER process and then summarize recently reported 2D nanomaterials developed for OER electrocatalysts.

sections.heading: 4.1. Transition-metal oxides
sections.text:
2D materials preparation method can be used to impart transitionmetal oxides (MOx), high specific surface area, short paths for
dsorption for enhanced ORR performance. (b) The schematic diagram of nitrobenzene m ref 82 and 77.
charge/mass transport, and rich surface reactive sites. However, low intrinsic activity and conductivity of a single metal component limited the improvement.
Doped Transition-Metal Oxides. A design principle has been established to link the intrinsic OER activity of perovskites with 3d electron occupancy to an eg orbital symmetry of the surface transition-metal cations. Some reports indicate that doping with certain elements can tailor the electronic structures of 2D MOx materials. For example, introduction of Fe into NiO materials can increase the oxidation ability of NiO and significantly improve their OER catalyticactivity [35,121]. Recent study, a porous NiFe oxide nanosheets were synthesized via a controlled transformation from LDH precursors [122]. Trimetallic oxyhydroxides are one of the most effective materials for oxygen evolution reaction (OER) catalysis. Nonetheless, if their structures and surfaces have not been precisely tuned, the reported transition-metal oxides and oxyhydroxides still needmuch higher overpotentials. Pi et al. report a general wet-chemical method for directly growing a trimetallic oxyhydroxide sponge on nickel foam (NF;W0.5Co0.5-xFex), as shown in Fig. 6 [123]. The presence of Fe in the trimetallic WCoFe oxyhydroxide is critical for OER activity enhancements, and the OER activity depends on the Fe content in a volcano-type fashion. The Co2þ/Co3þmolar ratio increases with the addition of Fe. XPS studies revealed that after addition of the correct amount of Fe, an on
average lower Co oxidation state in the trimetallic oxyhydroxides may optimize the binding energy of oxygen intermediates, which is the major factor in boosting the OER activity (see Fig. 7).
Defective Transition-Metal Oxides. Co3O4, which is of mixed valences Co2þ and Co3þ, has been extensively investigated as an efficient electrocatalyst for the oxygen evolution reaction (OER). Ultrathin porous Co3O4 nanosheets with porous structure have been synthesized from atomically thick CoO sheets which undergo a fast annealing process in air [124]. DFT calculations revealed that this enhanced catalytic activity is the result of low-coordinated surface Co3þ-atoms, which are more favorable for adsorbing H2O reactants. Wang et al. demonstrated an efficient Co3O4-based OER electrocatalyst by a plasma engraving strategy, which not only produced higher surface area, but also generated oxygen vacancies on Co3O4 nanosheet surface with more Co2þ formed [74]. The increased surface area ensures the Co3O4 has more sites for OER, and generated oxygen vacancies on Co3O4 surface improve the electronic conductivity and create more active defects for OER. And meanwhile, this as-developed plasma-engraving strategy provides a new strategy to design advanced electrocatalysts by increasing the surface area and generating surface oxygen vacancies simultaneously.
However, one may concern about the stability of VO, especially under the highly-oxidizing conditions of the OER process. It is big

challenge to stabilize the VO in Co3O4, while reserving the excellent activity. Filling the oxygen vacancies with heteroatoms in the VOrich Co3O4 may be a smart strategy to stabilize the VO by compensating the coordination numbers and to obtain an even surprising activity due to the modified electronic properties by heteroatoms. Xiao et al. successfully transformed VO-rich Co3O4 into a HER-OER electrocatalyst by filling the in situ formed VO in Co3O4 with phosphorus (PeCo3O4) through treating Co3O4 with Ar plasma in the presence of P precursor [126]. The relative lower coordination numbers in VO-Co3O4 than in pristine Co3O4 is evidenced by X-ray adsorption spectroscopy, indicating the oxygen vacancies are created after Ar plasma etching. On the other hand, the relative higher coordination numbers in PeCo3O4 than in VOCo3O4 and nearly having the same coordination number with pristine Co3O4 strongly suggest the efficient filling of P in the vacancies by treated with Ar plasma in the presence of P precursor. The theoretical calculations confirm that the improved electrical conductivity and intermediate binding by P-filling contributed significantly to the enhanced HER and OER activity of Co3O4.

sections.heading: 4.2. Transition-metal hydroxides
sections.text:
Doped Transition-Metal Hydroxides. A series of ultrathin single-layer LDH nanosheets were successfully synthesized and
showed significantly higher OER catalytic activity, owing to their increased number of active sites and improved electronic conductivity [126e130]. It is still highly desirable to obtain a fundamental understanding of the origin of outstanding OER activity on the surface of LDHs. Zhang et al. employed sAu supported on NiFe LDH (sAu/NiFe LDH) catalyst as a model to evaluate the OER activity and understand the activity origin at the atomic level (Fig. 8A) [131]. The high-angle annular dark field-scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM) image clearly shows individual Au atoms uniformly dispersed on the surface of NiFe LDH. Meanwhile, energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS)mapping images of sAu/ NiFe LDH suggest that atomic Au is evenly distributed over the entire nanosheet. Theoretical results demonstrate that active sites could be attributed to Fe atoms in NiFe oxyhydroxide supported by LDH and stabilized by CO32 anions and H2O. sAu could transfer electrons to LDH, changing the charge distribution and thus further improving the catalytic performance. This study may pave new avenues to the exploration and design of highly efficient electrocatalysts for energy conversion applications.
In addition, metal carbonate hydroxides have also been investigated and applied as OER electrocatalysts. For example, CoeMn carbonate hydroxide (CoMnCH) nanosheet, with controlled morphology and composition, were produced by doping Mn into Co carbonate hydroxide (CoCH) [132]. Mn doping not only
modulated the nanosheet morphology to significantly increase the ECSA, but also tuned the electronic structure of Co centers for effective enhancement of intrinsic catalytic activity.
Defective Transition-Metal Hydroxides. Unique 2D lamellar and electronic structure endows layered double hydroxides (LDHs) with excellent electrocatalytic properties. However, it is a big challenge to develop an efficient strategy to exfoliate bulk LDHs into stable monolayer LDHs nanosheets with more active sites exposed.Wang et al. developed a dry exfoliation of bulk Co3Fe LDHs into ultrathin by plasma (Fig. 9A). The formation of ultrathin Co3Fe LDHs nanosheets provides more exposed active sites for enhanced OER (Fig. 9D). More interestingly, the exfoliation was accompanied by the formation of multi-vacancies in the as-exfoliated ultrathin nanosheets. The existence of multi-vacancies can tune efficiently the surface electron structures, decrease the coordination number and increase the disorder degree of ultrathin nanosheets (Fig. 9C). The as-prepared ultrathin nanosheets can stably exist in the form of powders, probably due to the charge balancing by the residual CO32 and the environmental species such as moistures [133]. Later, wang et al. synthesized N-doped ultrathin CoFe LDHs nanosheets with edge-rich sites by etching bulk CoFe LDHs with N2 plasma [134]. It is a very facile and effective strategy to exfoliate the bulk CoFe LDHs into ultrathin nanosheets, tuning the number of the edge and corner active sites in 2D basal plane and carrying out the nitrogen doping in the ultrathin CoFe LDHs nanosheets. The assynthesized ultrathin NeCoFe LDHs nanosheets on Ni foam showed an excellent OER performance with an overpotential of 233 mV at the current density of 10 mA cm 2. The outstanding OER performance of ultrathin N-doped CoFe LDHs nanosheets is mainly attributed to high surface area of ultrathin nanosheets exposing more reactive sites for OER, more edge and corner sites bringing more dangling bonds and unsaturated coordination atoms to ultrathin nanosheets with higher electrocatalytic activity and Ndoping altering the electronic density of the adjacent metal atom and forming well-defined electronic congratulations for adsorption intermediates for OER.

sections.heading: 4.3. Metal Organic Framework (MOFs)
sections.text: Most MOF materials have relatively poor electrical conductivity resulting from their inherent molecular configuration. For example, ZIF-67, a Co-based MOF and Co2þ are uniformly distributed at the atomic scale. The question is how tomake use of these Co species as active sites for OER. But intrinsically, ZIF-67 shows poor catalytic activity for OER. The challenge is how to on-site transform the atomically distributed Co2þ in MOFs into atomic-scale active sites for OER. Dou et al. have applied O2 plasma to treat ZIF-67 to on-site produce atomic-scale CoOx species in ZIFs (CoOx-ZIF) as an efficient OER electrocatalyst [135]. The porous structure of MOFs provides pathways for O2 plasma to activate the atomically dispersed Co species. In addition, plasma is highly efficient for a rapid treatment, which would not severely destroy the bulk structure of MOFs during the treatment. Tao et al. utilized N2 plasma to remove some of the ligands attached to Co atoms to create coordinately unsaturated metal sites as the catalytic centers for OER [136]. DFT calculations also demonstrated the contribution of the unsaturated metal sites to the high catalytic activity for OER. Only a few works have been reported about the applications 2D MOFs in electrocatalysis. Very recently, Ultrathin 2D NiCo bimetallic MOF nanosheets (NiCo-UMOFNs) have been synthesized from a mixed solution of metal salts and benzene dicarboxylic acid under sonication for highly efficient OER [137].

sections.heading: 4.4. Black phosphorous
sections.text:
Due to the low stability of Black Phosphorus (BP) under electrocatalytic conditions, there is only a few works reported in electrocatalysis. Recently, it was found that various forms of bulk BP (such as thin films and particles) have electrocatalytic activities for the OER process comparable to commercial RuO2-based catalysts [137]. However, bulk BP has a low density of active sites which likely limits its electrocatalytic performance. Compared to its bulk form, 2D BP nanosheets synthesized by liquid exfoliation
techniques possess increased exposed active sites and surface area [138]. Therefore, the intrinsic benefits of this ultrathin lamellar structure can promote the development of BP for efficient electrocatalysis. As predicted, few-layered BP showed improved OER performance compared to the bulk form, achieving an onsetpotential of 1.45 V vs RHE (reversible hydrogen electrode) and Tafel slope of 88 mV dec 1 in alkaline conditions.

sections.heading: 4.5. MXenes
sections.text:
Despite these advantages, MXenes were limited used in OER by the fact that many highly active metal nitrides (such as cobalt, nickel, and iron) were not present in the MAX list. Pristine MXenes like Ti3C2Tx have low catalytic activity and are therefore hardly used directly as electrocatalysts. The hybridization methods have also been introduced to produce high performance MXene-based OER catalysts. Yu et al. reported a new type of non-precious metal electrocatalyst for OER by synergistically coupling layered double hydroxides (LDH) with two-dimensional (2D) MXene with high conductivity and active surface [141]. Hierarchical FeNi-LDH/Ti3C2MXene nanohybrids with excellent structural stability, electrical properties and interfacial junction are fabricated by ionic heteroassembly of interconnected porous network of FeNi-LDH nanoplates on Ti3C2 MXene nanosheets. Strong interfacial interaction and electronic coupling with prominent charge-transfer between the FeNi-LDH and Ti3C2 MXene is identified, which not only improves the structural stability and electrical conductivity of the nanohybrids, but also greatly accelerates the redox process of FeNiLDH for OER. Zhang et al. developed an in situ growth strategy compositing with carbon nanotubes (CNTs) supported on the surface of Ti3C2Tx MXene (Co/N-CNTs @Ti3C2Tx) as bifunctional electrocatalyst toward oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER) [34]. Xiu et al. reported a capillary-forced assembling strategy for processing MXene to hierarchical 3D architecture as catalyst carrier for CoP [142]. The CoP@3D Ti3C2MXene hybrid architecture exhibits high electrocatalytic activity toward OER and HER in KOH due to high conductivity, enlarged active surface area, accelerated charge and mass transport through
isotopically broadened pathway, and possible particle-MXene synergy.

sections.heading: 5. Surface-functional 2D nanomaterials for hydrogen evolution reaction
sections.text: In recent decades, designing high-performance HER electrocatalysts is critical for the development of clean energy at both fundamental and utilization levels. The intriguing structural and electronic properties of 2D nanomaterials provide new opportunities for exploring reaction performance. As a result, many new studies have explored various 2D structured electrocatalysts that can efficiently catalyze the HER [143,144]. In the following sections, we summarize recent progress on the application of 2D nanomaterials for the HER. We focus on typical 2Dmetal-free graphenebased, metallic TMDs materials and MXenes which demonstrate the combination of DFT computations and experimental observations for revealing the nature of the HER.

sections.heading: 5.1. Graphene based electrocatalysts
sections.text:
Heteroatom-Doped Graphene. Among various single heteroatom doped graphene materials, B-graphene shows the best specific HER activity [41]. However, it is still fairly poor compared to metallic MoS2 and Pt-based catalysts. N, Se, N, Pe, and N, B-graphene were chemically synthesized by annealing GO with selected precursors [145e147]. As predicted, it was found that dual doped samples showed enhanced HER activities compared to single doped samples (except N, B-graphene). Graphene is also considered to be an ideal support for single-atom catalysts. Atomically dispersing metal catalytic centers on graphene, especially earth-abundant elements, could be a promising approach for producing alternative HER catalysts to precious Pt metal. Cheng et al. reported a practical synthesis method to produce isolated single Pt-atoms and clusters on N-graphene using an atomic layer deposition technique [144]. The as-prepared single-Pt-atom catalyst exhibited a significantly higher HER activity than state-of-the-art Pt/C catalysts. DFT calculations confirmed that the excellent kinetics on this single atom
catalyst was attributed to its small activation barriers. Besides precious metals, atomic cobalt or Ni on N-graphene were obtained, it was found that a higher N doping level results in higher HER activity [146,147].

sections.heading: 5.2. Transition-metal dichalcogenides
sections.text: To date, TMDs are the biggest and most intensively studied group of 2D HER electrocatalysts. MoS2 is the most common TMD example. The earliest and the most common strategy for modifying the HER performance of MoS2 electrocatalysts is to enlarge its specific surface area [123,124,148e151]. This approach normally does not alter the electronic properties of pristine MoS2 but increase the number of activity sites. In the next sections, we briefly introduce several methods (e.g., heteroatom doping, Epitaxial growth, defect engineering, etc.) that have been used to tune the activity of catalytic sites.

sections.heading: 5.2.1. Heteroatom doping
sections.text:
Doping at the edge. Doping heteroatoms at the edge or in the basal plane of TMDs can modify their electronic structures and consequently increase the number of active sites [152]. Therefore, the identification of heteroatom doping sites in TMDs is crucial for revealing the effect that doping has on HER activity. Kibsgaard et al. found that Fe, Co, Ni, and Cu, could be doped into the S-edges of MoS2 and change the intrinsic activity of MoS2 [153]. Further, DFT calculations revealed the Co doping in MoS2 edges could activate the S-edges, which can then contribute to the active sites. 64 Wang et al. prepared a series of vertically standing, edge-terminated MoS2 nanofilms to ensure the transition-metal dopant (Co, Fe, Ni, Cu) un-doped in the Mo edge [154]. Electrochemical tests showed that the transition-metal-doped MoS2 nanofilms had an at least 2- fold increase activity. DFT study showed that the enhancement in activity should only be attributed to the modification of adsorption energy at the metal-doped S-edges.
Doping at the plane. The basal plane is considered to be inert for the HER. Heteroatomic doping in MoS2 basal plane is also a promising way of improving its HER activity. To date, metal (e.g., V, Pt) and non-metal (e.g., O, S) have been incorporated into MoS2 to tune its in-plane conductivity and intrinsic activity. For example, Xie et al. found that oxygen incorporation could effectively regulate the electronic structure of pristine MoS2 [47]. DFT calculations revealed that the DOS of the oxygen-incorporated MoS2 (OMoS2) slab had a much narrower bandgap (1.30 eV) than the pristine 2HeMoS2 slab (1.75 eV), indicating that oxygen incorporation could lead to more charge carriers and higher intrinsic conductivity (Fig. 10a). As a result, the best OeMoS2 sample is almost 40 times larger than that of bulk MoS2 (Fig. 10b). The authors attributed this high HER activity to the synergistic structural and electronic modulations caused by oxygen incorporation. The disordered structure offers large amounts of unsaturated S-edges as active sites for hydrogen adsorption and provides quasi-periodic arrangement of nanodomains, leading to fast interdomain electron transport (Fig. 10c). The oxygen incorporation in MoS2 enhances the intrinsic conductivity to facilitates charge transfer (Fig. 10d).
Besides non-metallic-atom doping, Sun et al. developed a novel intralayer vanadium doping strategy to produce semi-metallic VeMoS2 ultrathin nanosheets with less than five atomic layers for enhanced catalytic activity with smaller onset overpotential and Tafel slop [155]. Deng et al. demonstrated that the HER activity of in-plane S-atoms of MoS2 can also be tuned by single-metal-atom doping [64]. Using a one-pot chemical reaction, they prepared uniformly dispersed single Pt-atom-doped few-layer MoS2 nanosheets (PteMoS2) and the Pt-atom exactly occupied the position of one Mo atom. With computational techniques they confirmed that this direct replacement of in-plane Mo-atoms with Pt-atoms is the most stable configuration, and single-Pt-atom doping could activate the in-plane S-atoms for the HER. Experimentally, the trend of HER activity in these doping cases was Pt > Co > Ni.

Atomic substitution. Partially replacing S or Mo in MoS2 with other atoms can also continuously tune their compositions and band gaps, and provides the possibility to improve HER performance [107]. The most widely studied example of partial S replacement is with Se substitution. For example, few-layered MoS2(1 x)Se2x with tunable chemical compositions could be synthesized by a high-temperature solid-state reaction, a lowtemperature solution-based method, or CVD method, showed enhanced HER activity [156e158]. Replacing Mo-atoms with W to form an alloyed phase heterostructure is also an effective way to improve HER performance [159]. A novel Mo1 xWxS2 nanosheets

sections.heading: 5.2.2. Epitaxial growth
sections.text:
Epitaxial growth has been recognized as one of the most promising surface functionalization strategies towards the controlled growth of noble metal nanostructures (NSs) on 2D nanomaterials. As shown in Fig. 11, Zhang et al. developed an electrochemical in situ method noble metal NSs (e.g. Pt, Pd, Au and

Ag) for facile preparation of high-yield, large-amount, single-layer metal dichalcogenide (MoS2) nanosheets with solution-phase processablility [161]. The epitaxial growth of Pd, Pt and Ag NPs on MoS2 nanosheets has been realized at ambient conditions. Two types of epitaxial orientations, that is, the (111) and (101) orientations, have been found to coexist for most metal NPs. In addition, we demonstrate that the anisotropic NS, for example, (111)-oriented triangular Ag nanoplate, can also grow and epitaxially align on the MoS2 nanosheets. Importantly, the PteMoS2 hybrid nanomaterials have been used as promising catalysts for the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER), which exhibited much better electrocatalytic activity compared with the commercial Pt catalyst at the same Pt loading.

sections.heading: 5.2.3. Defect engineering
sections.text:
Introducing defects in the basal plane of TMDs can tune their band structures, and result in the generate of edges in basal plane, increasing the number of active sizes. Xie et al. reported a scalable process to engineer defects into MoS2 surfaces and expose active edge sites. This disordered atomic arrangement caused the cracking of the basal planes and thus resulted in the formation of additional edges [162]. Ye et al. introduced triangular holes inmonolayerMoS2 by O2 plasma treatment or H2 annealing of pristine MoS2, respectively [163]. The linearly increasing of current density of exposed edges could enhance the HER activity [31]. DFT calculations indicated that the optimal value when the concentration of S-vacancies is between 12 and 16% [164]. When S-vacancies are introduced, new bands appeared in the gap near the Fermi level and are responsible for hydrogen adsorption on the S-vacancies. Additionally, the more S vacancies, the closer the bands moved to the Fermi level. A study was carried out which introduced S-vacancies in monolayer 2HeMoS2 nanosheets using Ar plasma treatment. Electrochemical experiment results confirmed that monolayer 2HeMoS2 with S-vacancies had better performance compared to pristine monolayer 2HeMoS2 from both apparent and intrinsic activity perspectives. More recently, Tsai et al. developed a novel route toward generating S-vacancies on the MoS2 basal plane (VeMoS2) using an electrochemical desulfurization process [165]. Specifically, under a certain negative potential, sulfur atoms in the basal planewould be hydrogenated and then removed as H2S gas to form S-vacancies for highly efficient HER. DFT calculation showed

that the formation of S-vacancies in the basal plane are thermodynamically favorable at a sufficiently negative potential and the concentration of S-vacancies could be varied by changing the applied voltage.

sections.heading: 5.3. Transition-metal hydroxide
sections.text: Doped transition-metal hydroxide. NiFe-layered double hydroxide (NiFe-LDH) has emerged as a promising electrocatalyst for catalyzing water splitting, especially oxygen evolution reaction (OER), in alkaline solutions. Unfortunately, as a result of extremely sluggish water dissociation kinetics (Volmer step), hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) activity of the NiFe-LDH is rather poor in alkaline environment. Chen et al. demonstrated a novel approach to tailor the water dissociation active sites on NiFe-LDH by partially substituting Fe centerswith Ru dopants (Fig.12) [65]. The Ru-doped NiFe-LDH nanosheets were in situ grown on commercial nickel foam using a one-pot hydrothermal reaction at 120 C. Remarkably, the resultant NiFeRu-LDH exhibited excellent HER activity with an overpotential as low as 29 mV at a current density of 10 mA cm 2 and a substantially decreased Tafel slope of 31 mV decade 1 in a 1m KOH aqueous solution, which surpassed those values for the Pt/ C catalyst (31 mV at 10 mA cm 2) and state-of-the-art Pt-free electrocatalysts. Both experimental and density functional theory (DFT) calculation results revealed that the substitution of Ru dopants to Fe centers of the NiFe-LDH efficiently reduced the kinetic energy barrier of the Volmer step and thereby accelerated the HER process under alkaline conditions. Moreover, the excellent OER activity of the NiFe-LDH (an overpotential of 225 mV at 10 mA cm 2) was well retained after the Ru doping. The DFT calculations disclosed that the introduction of Ru into the NiFe-LDH could efficiently lower the kinetic energy barrier of the Volmer step and eventually to enhance the HER performance.

sections.heading: 6. Nitrogen reduction reaction
sections.text:
Ammonia (NH3) is an essential chemical that is widely used in agriculture and industry applications. Ammonia is predominantly synthesized via the Haber-Bosch process with Fe-based catalysts at High temperature and pressure conditions, consuming ~1.5% of global energy consumption with a significant CO2 emission [166].
EM and e) low-resolution HAADF-STEM images of the NiFeRu-LDH. (B) a) Polarization e Volmer step and d) the Tafel step on the as-built NiFe-LDH and NiFeRu-LDH models.
The condition of electrocatalytic N2 reduction reaction (NRR) is ambient, using water as the hydrogen source. NRR has been proposed as a sustainable alternative for ammonia production, but its efficiency has generally been extremely low [167]. It is worth noting that current studies on the NRR mainly rely on theoretical calculations. Therefore, 2D nanomaterials for the NRR is a relatively new research field.
Li et al. developed a 2D hybrid composite of amorphous Au nanoparticles, CeO2, and rGO for the NRR [168]. The noble metal content of the resultant catalyst was low (1.31 wt% Au) and the existence of CeOx promoted the formation of amorphous/lowcrystalline Au nanoparticles. At a potential of 0.2 V vs RHE, the NH3 generation rate and Faradaic efficiency on this catalyst was 8.3 mg h 1 mg 1 and 10.1%, respectively. Yan et al. takes PdCu amorphous nanocluster anchored on reduced graphene oxide (rGO) as NRR catalysts, the optimum Pd0.2Cu0.8/rGO composite presents a synergistic effect and shows superior electrocatalytic performance toward NRR under ambient conditions (yield: 2.80 mg h 1 mgcat. 1 ) at 0.2 V vs reversible hydrogen electrode), which is much higher than that of monometallic, especially noble metal, counterparts [169]. Zheng et al. demonstrate that twodimensional (2D), boron-doped graphene (BG) features as an ideal NRR electrocatalyst that can promote adsorption of N2, shown in Fig. 13. The graphene (G) framework doped with boron atoms can retain its original sp [2] hybridization and conjugated planar structure. The positively charged boron atoms are beneficial for adsorbing N2, thus providing excellent catalytic centers for the BeN bond formation and the subsequent production of NH3. These electron-deficient boron sites can also prohibit the binding of Lewis acid Hþ at these sites, which can promote the NRR faradic efficiency (FE) and decrease of HER. At a boron doping concentration of 6.2%, BG exhibited an excellent NH3 yield (9.8 mg h 1 mg 1) and one of the highest Fes (10.8%) for NH3 production in aqueous solutions at ambient conditions at 0.5 V versus reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE), corresponding to 5-fold and 10-fold increases of the NH3
yield and FENH3, respectively, of undoped G. Further, no hydrazine was detected. For the photocatalytic NRR, Zhao et al. demonstrated that LDH nanosheets could be used directly as photocatalysts for artificial dinitrogen fixation under ambient conditions. The oxygen vacancies of the LDH nanosheets enhanced the adsorption and activation of N2 and H2O, which contributed to their excellent photocatalytic NRR activity [170].

sections.heading: 7. Conclusion and outlook
sections.text:
Recently, the continuing interest in the 2D ultrathin nanomaterials has been boomed for electrocatalytic Reaction. We focus on recent attempts to discuss the concerning surface chemical modification strategies of surface atom incorporation, defect engineering, and structure modulation, which could respectively enhance the intrinsic electrical conductivity, optimizing the reaction energy barrier while maintaining the primary 2D structural stability. Then, we listed the surface-functionalization 2D materials for enhanced electrocatalytic processes involved in the ORR, OER, HER and NRR, as well as density functional theoretical (DFT) calculation to study the relationship between electronic structure, adsorption energy, and apparent activity sites. Although many special properties exist for 2D electrocatalysts, there is also faced with many challenges.
First, because 2D ultrathin nanosheets have a high surface energy, we need to focus our attention on thermodynamic and chemical stability in extreme electrolyte environments (mostly strongly acid for HER and alkali for OER). Second, regarding the electrocatalytic reaction process, mass transport plays an equally important role but has long been neglected in relation to electron transfer in existing reports. Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) with inartificial regular porous structures as mass delivery channels could be an excellent model system for optimizing mass transport, although they have poor intrinsic conductivity. Third, for application of functional device like solid polymer electrolyte (SPE), the
widely application of acid proton exchange membrane is not suitable for the routine OER and HER catalysts used in alkaline condition. In acid condition, precious metals are still the most suitable catalysts. Surface chemical-functionalization of unthin twodimensional strategy may provide the possibility for the efficient use of precious metals. Forth, efficiency of nitrogen reduction reaction has generally been extremely low. The catalyst should facilitate the chemisorption of N2molecules for sufficient activation of its inert NN triple bond and (2) the catalyst should selectively stabilize N2H* and (3) destabilize NH2* species to reduce the overpotential required. The large number of species, special structures and the adjustable electronic distribution of unthin twodimensional nanomaterial by surface chemical-functionalization will provide great potential for NRR. All in all, we are confident that such an integrated approach will help facilitate the rapid development of both basic research and electrocatalytic reaction applications.

metadata.abstractText: In the past few decades, with the development of energy conversion and storage technology, twodimensional (2D) ultrathin nanomaterials with single or few atomic layers have been extensively studied as efficient electrocatalysts due to their unique physical, chemical, and electronic properties. The unique ultrathin structure provides an alternative way of modifying the surface phase or electronic structure for engineering the intrinsic electrocatalysts properties. Here, we focus on recent attempts to discuss the concerning surface chemical modification strategies of surface atoms incorporation, defect engineering, and surface structure modulation, which could respectively enhance the intrinsic electrical conductivity, optimizing the reaction energy barrier while maintaining the primary 2D structural stability. Following this review, we listed the surface-functional 2D materials for enhanced electrocatalytic processes involved in the water splitting, oxygen/nitrogen reduction reactions, as well as density functional theoretical (DFT) calculation to study the relationship between electronic structure, adsorption energy, and apparent activity sites. Finally, we also present some challenges and opportunities of surface chemical-functionalization of ultrathin 2D nanomaterials for electrocatalysis. © 2019 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
